title: Jesus Christ's Mission Continues in the Church
subject: Theology

document.title: Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age

A084F94A68F64F0980A3628BA5DB96DA.description:
The unity of the Church is also sustained through
the common celebration of worship and the
sacraments (CCC, no. 815).

36E3A5E5CCF14AE1A247CA9143BC8875.description:
It is the pope and bishops who are the successors in
every age to St. Peter and the Apostles (CCC, nos.
815, 862).

E40770D67A7C45F1A15A92D20AA41ACF.description:
The Church is able to sustain unity because she
has the apostolic teaching office of the pope and
bishops to guide and direct her under the guidance
of the Holy Spirit (CCC, no. 815).

50CBBF4C7AEB4AC69EDAF46B21FEFF4B.description:
How is it that the Catholic Church is able to sustain
the unity of her members even though they live out
their faith in different cultures and sometimes express
their faith in different ways?

BE190C6C37A147C09DA9B2368ECAF6A1.description:
The Catholic Church is structured so that all the
members, clergy and laity alike, are accountable to
someone (CCC, nos. 871-879).

6FCDBA3FFBFD42BCB3A6EEFA821640D8.description:
God taught in the Old and New Testaments for
people to come together and worship in the way
that he revealed to them (CCC, nos. 1093-1097).

FB98A35FA6EE498C8E79FEAB916DD566.description:
The Church offers us authentic worship in spirit
and in truth when we unite ourselves with Christ’s
self-offering in the Mass (CCC, nos. 1322-1324).

02C62CBED33B4D6CBA48393E5AB15F46.description:
Worship of God has both a personal dimension and
a communal dimension: personal, private worship
is encouraged to complement communal worship
(CCC, nos. 821, 1136-1144).

ED9C4FAEF3234D85909438B9AB1C4618.description:
Because human beings are social in nature, we need
each other’s encouragement, support, and example
(CCC, no. 820).

4639A7AD216E42CFAFF5BD4F76F12005.description:
No one and no community can proclaim the
Gospel to themselves (CCC, no. 875).

AB2D3E7F098D4FFE923FD06844665792.description:
God desires us to come to him as members of
his family, his new people, so he established the
Church to accomplish that purpose (CCC, no.
760).

8D752843F46949E796C477595273FED3.description:
Who needs organized religion? Isn’t it better to worship
God in my own way, when and how I want?

F177539C65CB469BA159D7F43A0BE9B1.description:
The Church is guided and animated by the Holy
Spirit and, as the Body of Christ, remains sinless
even if her members sin.

28CC83DE58C542388D39C6CC0908F911.description:
The Church teaches what God has told us about
how to be holy and the necessity of avoiding sin.
Failure by members of the Church to live out what
God has taught does not invalidate the truth of the
teaching we have received through the Apostles
and their successors.

5F1A7076B4424702B6A1269EAB6057BD.description:
Some members of the Church might be
hypocritical. Members of the Church, like
all human beings, are guilty of sin, but this doesn’t
make the Church wrong or hypocritical.

DB1B7A9B2F28476986D19F98AE488208.description:
Isn’t the Church being hypocritical in telling other
people to be holy and avoid sin when many Catholics,
including the clergy, are guilty of terrible wrongs (CCC,
nos. 823-829)?

16D69F69B5774079BD4EF58234EB0A82.description:
Members of the Catholic Church have the duty to
evangelize others (CCC, nos. 849-856).

22003FAD3D2343C7A94D51EFB8704F91.description:
Those who through no fault of their own do not
know Christ or the Catholic Church are not
excluded from salvation; in a way known to God,
all people are offered the possibility of salvation
through the Church (CCC, nos. 836-848).

AFD093C87D0A40FEACD015B1157EF4B3.description:
Christ established his Church as a visible
organization through which he communicates his
grace, truth, and salvation (CCC, no. 771).

ABD9CAD7131A4B0BAF7B9C0E06753FC0.description:
Christ willed that the Catholic Church be his
sacrament of salvation, the sign and the instrument
of the communion of God and man (CCC, nos.
774-776, 780).

2133708C940049A4B560664B5E30C279.description:
To be a Catholic is to be a member of the one true
Church of Christ. While elements of truth can be
found in other churches and religions, the fullness
of the means of salvation subsists in the Catholic
Church (CCC, nos. 816, 836-838).

CFD7A5DBEE82421B9123DCD97A9D10DA.description:
Why do I have to be a Catholic? Aren’t all religions as
good as another (CCC, nos. 760, 817-822, 836)?

0AA92428B13B48059B4FD055D21C058F.description:
Prayer helps us understand the teachings of
Jesus Christ and his Church in a deeper way
and live them more fully.

76375FEC39304A99BEECF76592478CC2.description:
The Lord forms, teaches, guides, consoles, and
blesses us through prayer.

AAC2B66025C548F3A79B7F70235C2748.description:
Examples for Christian witness in parish
and diocese.

A29E745359CA4036ACBEA63744E90479.description:
Active response to call to holiness at home,
workplace, public square.

69A903C764DD4FC3AAA511785354AAC0.description:
Living as Christ calls and teaches us as known
in and through the Church.

D811300C9B3549E1A33B10FC4068C749.description:
As disciples of Christ we are “salt and light for
the world.”

D0A94DACAD3F4076B044B83B4B1CB949.description:
Living as a member of the Church, the Body of Christ,
means we live as disciples, proclaiming the Lord Jesus’
teaching to others (CCC, nos. 520, 1248).

A5E2914A5041464C8F17635B124B2B2C.description: Celebration of the Christian mysteries (CCC, nos.1273, 1389).

CE73B4F32E00425E9A8F35FC25D0B7BA.description:
Through association with others who want to
follow Christ in the Church.

B3D1ED965F2A4E6E8694DE8A0298A6F7.description:
Through a life of prayer, communion, charity,
service, and justice in the household of faith.

5977B90FD1DB4ED69592DEA9BC7E30C2.description: Jesus Christ enriches us through the Church.

9302C77D05AB47B381BA2D709EFFD213.description:
Church has fullness of truth and totality of the
means of salvation.

5F9E26630E0E43F7AF8A6BD48FE3C46B.description:
Christ entrusted Word and sacraments to the
Church for our salvation.

096F9F9699B148958B6824E4104D1317.description:
We receive Christ’s redemption as members of his
Body the Church.

6DDB7731819A4C099327A3F384E3D917.description:
Christ willed the Church to be the ordinary way
and means of salvation (CCC, no. 763, 772-776).

95B8254E098B44CE9CB620EDF07DED6F.description: Belonging to the Church is essential (CCC, no. 760).

8771C2226C014EEE9E83B32ACC06DADC.description: Implications for Life of a Believer

A40DA7A901E74940AE209E69360DE166.description:
Bishops have responsibility to govern their
particular churches; they are to exercise their
authority and sacred power with the Good
Shepherd as their model.

9FC3347698ED48A08AEC47A7287AD54D.description:
The pope, the bishop of Rome, exercises supreme,
ordinary, and immediate jurisdiction over the
universal Church.

75A8285494BE4BA68FD3721D3FA1C09E.description: Governing office of the Church (CCC, nos. 894-896).

258F555F9CCD43EE85EBE435B7954D9E.description: Goal for all is eternal life.

16DE1C0017E745A4B769C2E8C8045C1C.description:
Bishops and priests sanctify the Church by
prayer, work and ministry of the Word, and the
sacraments.

A8D46F3CD7BF4E4987C6A0DD675F9F96.description: The Eucharist is the center of life in the Church.

C1ACD2DE80284DC2A8317EB6BFCF71D8.description: Sanctifying office of the Church (CCC, no. 893).

3799D17B17234B89AD7924C9DAAF39EE.description:
Disciplines of the Church can be adjusted by
the hierarchy for new circumstances.

56716EF171F34B319D3CBCCE2A4BAD7F.description:
Pastoral norms for living the faith and moral
life, e.g., the precepts of the Church.

CD7C9411D7E64CC6B33E93BB653F8AF6.description:
The pope and bishops exercise infallibility
when they teach together either in regular
teaching dispersed throughout the world
or when gathered in an ecumenical
council (CCC, no. 892).

9F26FEF9F5D9483E860BB8A63666B0BA.description:
The pope can exercise infallibility when
teaching alone on faith and morals, when
the teaching is held in common by the
bishops of the world and the pope declares
that he is teaching ex cathedra (CCC,
no. 891).

4CF1BE9C40464FFDB0D46D1CE7278E3B.description:
Infallibility: the gift of the Holy Spirit, which
gives the Church the ability to teach faith and
morals without error.

C7F38C7E89F2449AB2B36832C3586D01.description:
Indefectibility: the Church will always teach
the Gospel of Christ without error even in
spite of the defects of her members, both
ordained and lay.

876E4AD7A48340F79F2E461139BEE82C.description:
The Ordinary Magisterium must be accepted
even when it is not pronounced in a
definitive manner.

44663356CF934EA19C2CE1392685EC45.description:
Ensure fidelity to teachings of the Apostles on
faith and morals (CCC, Glossary).

397F33F55FD24C3C9DC54B65FB04659E.description:
Authentic interpreters of God’s Word in
Scripture and Tradition.

CA459294A9BC4DDC9EFE23BF7B2BC355.description: The teaching role of the pope and bishops.

0D549C1E24044A36A99B071205E60DF6.description:
Teaching office in the Church: the Magisterium (CCC,
no. 890).

E63B251ABE454AC8ADF99557DE01CE6D.description:
The laity live in various states of life: a) Marriage and family life.
b) Single life.
c) Third orders and lay consecrated
people.

BD3BBE58492C424BB1FE9727367D805C.description:
Some of the laity work full time for
the Church.

DF63A838D0E242B0BE7EBD53BDC0AC85.description:
Evangelization and sanctification of
the world.

46948B4E439D461C9E8B657AFBF46395.description:
Laity: baptized members of Christ (CCC, nos.
897-913).

60D911838DBA4BAD98093AC0D2A22907.description:
Religious: consecrated by vows to Christ
(CCC, nos. 925-933).

529F04E9F21F42A1A891D3702E0EDB86.description:
Ordained deacons continue the ministry of
Christ the Servant (CCC, nos. 1569-1571).

479A675CD14C44FC95684C4A35DB3C55.description:
Ordained bishops, diocesan and religious
priests continue the ministry of Christ the
Head (CCC, nos. 1555-1568).

CBB4BD698CBF421094AB62AF6F069064.description:
The College of Bishops in union with the pope as
its head.

249838B2C21E4EA8A382AF12C00654A8.description:
Visible structure of the Church: a hierarchical
communion (CCC, nos. 880-896).

C593E9187574461A83D667BA64A7E512.description:
The Church and her mission of evangelization (CCC,
nos. 861, 905).

B31FE090E795411C827E921B876BDAE5.description:
Church scrutinizes “signs of the times”—interprets
them in light of Gospel.

4B3FF2621E5547B5B3D2E2121342304A.description:
Church continues Christ’s salvation, preserves and
hands on his teaching.

CCAE2917BD1445959B7972ED343C7389.description: Church transcends history yet is part of history.

987D837A04FE45CE86D1F4F06DDB4D12.description:
Jesus—not the members—endowed Church with
authority, power, and responsibility (CCC, nos.
763-766).

CF23E68707C942D3BF5EEAD8D3513F62.description:
Christ founded the Church with a divine purpose and
mission (CCC, no. 760).

6DDBEF6F163645B593E4BB5EEB953569.description:
The Church is sign and instrument of communion with
God and unity of the human race (CCC, no. 760).

BEB5C6731C754B07AA621587E9942CBF.description:
Christ calls all Church members to share Gospel
of salvation.

311CBFAC2B0448B5A8C1980F3A0EB5AC.description:
Guided by successors of the Twelve: the pope
and bishops.

3110C5A9BC50416A9C69ACB1BF416E5B.description:
Has apostolic mission and teaching of Scripture
and Tradition.

F94D8DB4D2B14CC2AAC4E372CDF6A6D1.description:
Founded by Christ on the Twelve with the primacy
of Peter.

B060B669C32A421A87AE75AC6DC2491F.description:
Salvation comes from the Church even for nonmembers (see Dominus Iesus, section 20; CCC,
no. 1257).

2F73545469DE40FC8C93F9577C932373.description:
The Church exists for all people and is the means
to salvation for all people.

65BEA05CC7434ACCB6ECBD2EE01224B6.description:
The Church has been sent by Christ on a mission
to the whole world and exists worldwide.

56D5F5AA650A48A4BF5B60EFBE8CBB7C.description:
The members of the Church are always in need
of purification, penance, and renewal (LG, no. 8,
cited in CCC, nos. 827, 1428; UR, no. 6, cited in
CCC, no. 821).

2FEB2D7E22214F0B8CB3D7CE92C2738F.description:
The Immaculate Conception and the
Assumption.

97B77FA1CD7B4B5FB1E8FFC054ACEC2D.description: The Annunciation and Mary’s “yes” to God.

DC7ADC212CD04DA480B12D625038DC16.description: Mary, Mother of the Church and model of faith.

E28DD5422BC84EA0B167FE2DFD80AFDE.description:
Church constantly fosters conversion
and renewal.

BD7058E005924640BA24403B445E7153.description:
Church members sin, but the Church as Body of
Christ is sinless.

E2E463CA0BA746AD80F6CA58B027B26B.description: Church members must cooperate with God’s grace.

4971230A44B54C4BA7E38E4F3B974971.description:
Christ sanctifies the Church through the Holy
Spirit and grants the means of holiness to the
Church.

8190E6042AB04CC999FC99EFD68D9BBF.description:
Holiness is from the all-holy God: all human beings
are called to live in holiness.

2AC64088884A4579AE659A9203A49400.description:
Judaism, which holds a unique place in
relation to the Catholic Church.

FCA6FF4DEF5F4F0D932D2FB4B62E144F.description:
The fullness of Christ’s Church subsists in the
Catholic Church (LG, no. 8).

2560D0E1A4744657A0495A15483ED9B0.description:
Ecumenical dialogues with Orthodox
Churches and Protestant ecclesial and faith
communities emphasized common baptism
of all Christians and common service to love
even to the point of joint-martyrdom.

1281844779BE4288A8C6312583C89B8B.description:
Jesus’ prayer for unity of his disciples (Jn 17:11;
CCC, no. 820).

AB8233885ECB4F8DB029F27FE47BF099.description:
Eastern Schism of 1054: the pope in
Rome and the bishop of Constantinople
excommunicated each other, thus
leading to the breach between the
Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern
Orthodox Church.

72366C92CA0A40C5AD1F1799F5D89787.description:
Following the Council of Chalcedon in
451, those who accepted the Monophysite
position formed what are called the
Oriental Orthodox Churches.

533834FE193645B4893B3A824689661E.description:
Following the Council of Ephesus in 431,
those Churches which followed Nestorius
established separate Churches; later
returned to union with Rome.

0991B4AB99C8408491F43BE5DFBD00BC.description: Schisms (the split between East and West).

916A196C4DFC4D54B084EC2123F9B5D2.description:
Protestant Reformation: emphasized sola
scriptura (the Bible alone) and sola gratia
(grace alone).

834E8E3DB8D54AA2978FE9B4DC72D43A.description:
Early Church heresies: Gnosticism,
Arianism, Nestorianism, Monophysitism,
and Apollinarianism (CCC, nos. 464,
466-467, 471).

F86243DF608F4D49A28B37AE97574154.description:
Communion of twenty-one Eastern Catholic
Churches and one Western Church, all in
union with the Pope.

A2C8BFEA36954CD7A406B82E4092BF21.description:
Multiplicity of peoples, cultures, and liturgical
traditions (CCC, nos. 814, 1202).

5E8D1460F4F74EFE811B656712D2B687.description:
The Church is united in charity, in the profession
of one faith, in the common celebration of worship
and sacraments, and in Apostolic Succession
(CCC, no. 815).

BB21C6F499C64BE49FCCEC6DC3F95C7C.description:
Unity is in Jesus Christ through the Holy Spirit; it
is visible unity in the world.

B6E81D1550AC47D9817C9AB065EC7752.description: Images rooted in Scripture and developed in Tradition.

78035FBFB8454182B5F701C9F5076FAF.description:
The seed and the beginning of the Kingdom (CCC,
nos. 541, 669, 764, 768).

EA0081BFC06D489AB08AB3F25EAE7360.description:
The temple of the Holy Spirit (CCC, nos. 797-
801).

59086A3BC353470995A902FE02BDFAA9.description:
The remnant foretold by the prophets (CCC,
no. 762).

13FDEC90F09940B6BDA74D8BCEB96667.description:
Israel’s election as the People of God (CCC,
no. 762).

7EBE9265ACC242C9B66706AF175A226C.description:
The call of Abraham, and the promise to him of
descendants (CCC, no. 762).

A5588860FB534D4EABE739EB7B277AA3.description:
Images of the Church (Partial Insights of
Church Sharing in Trinitarian Communion)

B75D92D2BF694399ACFF24BC8657F350.description:
Community of Apostles continued in community
of pope and bishops (CCC, nos. 861-862).

D51A8645465B41C2A7333D1ABCB404C2.description:
The Council of Jerusalem: the Apostles recognized
as leaders of the Church (CCC, no. 860).

4237ED6E92954A3885088BEB5B22B398.description:
Chosen and appointed by Jesus Christ (CCC, nos.
857-860).

E8ED075D28114F7D8F4DB6FEE1F06A8B.description:
The role of the Apostles in the early Church
(CCC, no. 857).

74EF1AE077B94EB59FFC311D3AB83DE0.description:
The development of the New Testament
(CCC, nos. 124-133).

A25081104EA4410EAFB7306E66946559.description:
Handing on the teaching of Jesus (CCC, nos. 787-789,
792, 796).

27331A0364674E5BBA17D1F80946AC74.description: The conversion of St. Paul (CCC, no. 442).

50560382BE7042AEA8569B1FABD3383B.description:
The Church spreads to the Gentiles (CCC, nos.
762, 774-776, 781).

2AD8F1A7341847A78E4EF7069E822C55.description:
Conflict with Jewish and Roman authorities (CCC,
no. 2474).

1A6873055B9546B696AAB77F751CA34E.description: The growth of the Church (CCC, nos. 766-769).

328B77F2F21246B1B8257629F7B396C0.description:
The preaching of Peter on Pentecost (CCC,
nos. 551-556).

C6A98F34D2BD411A8D059107185F6EDC.description:
Holy Spirit inspires Apostles’ mission (CCC, nos.
857, 860).

9943DC83AC424417A1216A7AF1B9EE44.description:
The Spirit’s gifts help the Church to fulfill her
mission (CCC, no. 768; LG, no. 4).

2E953822D5374ED39E45298C790934A6.description:
The Holy Spirit bestows varied hierarchic and
charismatic gifts upon the Church.

F7F61147B6C148F0974CC2D27EC7657F.description: Spirit present in and through the Church.

56A5D7893C09464F8B4EC813C1426D23.description:
Holy Spirit is present in the entire Church (CCC, nos.
737-741).

E4BF912C7E8046B0BE172845A31D1FD6.description: The events of the first Pentecost.

7D8F90AA073D47F5BD67F75F94B7F8D3.description:
The descent of the Holy Spirit (CCC, nos. 696, 731-
732, 767, 1076, 1287, 2623).

E0E8354D926446ED9FCE21B0344B5D5E.description:
Church is pillar and foundation of truth (1 Tm
3:15; CCC, no. 768).

1CF2652626E54158A712687F365B70BD.description:
The Holy Spirit revealed the Church at Pentecost
(CCC, nos. 767-768).

EB8E7633391C487B94B098D16412F97C.description:
The Church is born primarily of Christ’s total
self-giving (CCC, no. 766).

DD8EC63348E942A9BA53C267A977CDEC.description:
Christ endowed his community with a
structure that will remain until the Kingdom is
fully achieved (CCC, no. 765).

7E5CDFAF11A447AD85D1C64F0ABD5F85.description:
Christ inaugurated the Church by preaching
Good News (CCC, nos. 767-768).

FBE4C5405B3D4E9E8CFEA1E891F9E596.description:
The Catholic Church was instituted by Christ
(CCC, nos. 748-766).

8E7FEF27FD53426E9092B24D7573CAED.description:
Preparation for the Church begins with God’s
promise to Abraham (CCC, no. 762).

D6DFF652715540A180E0414B83977D28.description:
The Church—planned by the Father (LG, no. 2;
CCC, no. 759).

7FB91E107AD1417BAB5463B188A303A7.description:
The origin, foundation, and manifestation of the
Church (CCC, nos. 778-779).

B7609B78DC5C407D9D489DB62C9223F8.description:
Christ Established His One Church to
Continue His Presence and His Work
